elements.text: PART ONE
PRE-TITLES:
SCENE 1. EXT. BY THE GATE AT THE END OF ALL THINGS
MUSIC: DRUMS. TRUMPETS. PIPE ORGAN. A SYMPHONY FOR THE BIG
CRUNCH.
THE OLD UNIVERSE IS DYING. ALL IS BLACKNESS AS THE LAST OF
EXISTENCE CONTRACTS AT A TERRIBLE SPEED TOWARDS NOTHING.
HOWEVER, A GATE IS ABOUT TO OPEN INTO THE UNIVERSE BEYOND, A
UNIVERSE WHICH IS DUE TO BE BORN A FRACTION OF A SECOND AFTER
THE DEATH OF ITS PREDECESSOR.
ALL LIFE HAS BEEN EXTINGUISHED, SAVE FOR THREE REMAINING
THE AIRBORNE DEMI-GODS THE SHEPHERD AND THE SHEPHERDESS AND THEIR FLOATING COMPUTERISED GUIDE, THE SYLPH.
IN THE GATHERING DARKNESS, THE SYLPH IS WAITING FOR THE SHEPHERD AND THE SHEPHERDESS. WHEN THE SYLPH SPEAKS, HER VOICE HAS SOMETHING OF THE QUALITY OF PLAINSONG.
My lord and lady! You must hurry! We have but two minutes till universal extinction.
Well met, my gentle lady Shepherdess.
Well met, good Shepherd. Now, is all prepared?
Aye. All’s in readiness. You have my word. The Gate will open soon to set us free,
So that we might depart this old and gored, Weak, worn and falling inward universe.
Thou hast done well, my dear and noble friend.
FX: CRACKLE AND ROAR AS A SCHISM — THE GATE — APPEARS IN THE
FABRIC OF THE OLD UNIVERSE.
My lord and lady! The gate doth open! The gate doth open! But it shall not be open long.
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 3 of
And yet how often have we done this, friend? How often have we stood before the Gate
At end of all as an old universe,
So rotted, cankered, full of age, is lost?
“How often?” Now, why ask thou such a thing? It matters not how oft we stand before
The Gate. We are the gods of old and new. Our centuries are stones upon the beach.
I believe that I have come to envy
Certain of those tiny, speck-like creatures Who live and breathe and creep and multiply Upon the worlds of ev’ry universe.
I’ve jealous grown of their small mayfly lives. They must more deeply feel than you or I.
My friend, these thoughts are not for thinking now.
My lord and lady! The end approaches! We have but one minute till universal extinction. We must pass at once into the gat
But there are tender words which I must share.
This sentiment of yours is most unlike

The Shepherdess whose wisdom and cool art Hath overseen and judged a billion worlds. The Gate is closing and we must pass through. In this we will not merely save ourselves But all the denizens as yet unborn,
Undreamed of, in that fledgling paradise. They are our sheep and our good counsel need.
My Lord! My Lady! The Gate doth start to close. We must pass through. There are just thirty seconds till the end of all things.
My lady, list! The Sylph doth urge our flight.
(REALLY FRANTIC NOW) Twenty-five seconds till the end of all things! Twenty-four seconds! Twenty-three- [seconds! ]
e!
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 4 of 129
TIME HAS BEEN STOPPED. BY MENTAL ENERGY ALONE, THE SHEPHERDESS IS HOLDING BACK THE DESTRUCTION OF THE OLD UNIVERSE.
LIKE A STUCK RECORD, THE SYLPH, HELD IN STASIS, REPEATS THE SAME PHRASE OVER AND OVER.
Twenty-three- Twenty-three- Twenty-three- [Twenty-three- ]
Now, hush, my Sylph.
THE SYLPH FALLS SILENT. NO AMBIENT NOISE.
What marvel hast thou wrought?
Time’s halted with imagination’s pow’r.
But thou shouldst not have thwarted nature so.
I mean to tell thee this, my gentle friend: I have come to know that I do love thee.
My lady!
But dost thou not think the same?
Long I have dreamed of those words that you spoke.
Your affirmation fills me with great joy.
My love.
It is as though we’ve sloughed our skins, And our true selves reveal’d.
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 5 of 129
And yet, my love, Thy spell decays. The dark draws near. The Gate Doth close. And we, my Shepherdess, are lost.
FX: WITH A WHOOSH, TIME STARTS AGAIN. THE SYLPH RECOVERS.
My lord! My lady! We have but seconds till the end arrives!
Pray take my hand. We have no time to chart Our course. And so unguided must we pass The Gate into the formless void beyond.
Fly! Fly! The end is come!
This ancient universe hath almost died.
Yet with new love into the next we glide.
FX: THE SHEPHERD, THE SHEPHERDESS AND THE SYLPH PASS THROUGH
THE GATE.
FX: THE GATE CLOSES AND THE OLD UNIVERSE FINALLY DIES.
FOR A MOMENT THERE IS ONLY SILENCE.
TITLE MUSIC
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 6 of 129
SCENE 2. INT. PUB — LONDON, 1990
WILL ARROWSMITH IS RETURNING FROM THE CROWDED BAR WITH A DRINK IN EACH HAND. ELIZABETH KLEIN IS WAITING FOR HIM AT A SMALL TABLE. WILL REACHES HER, PASSES HER ONE OF THE DRINKS AND TAKES A SEAT.
There we go, Dr Klein. One white wine spritzer.
Thank you, Will. And what are you drinking?
It’s a pint of something called “Lusty Pikeman”. I admit it: I was taken with the title.
I thought you weren’t going to have anything alcoholic?

It wasn’t planned. I did order a lemonade but the barman gave me such a dirty look when I asked that I... buckled. Peer pressure, I suppose. If one considers a very large man with a shaved head and a lot of tattoos one’s peer. I don’t know. Was that rude? It wasn’t supposed to be rude. (FX: PUSHES PINT ASIDE) I’1l just leave it, I think. (BEAT) Anyway.
Anyway.
You wanted a word?
Now, it’s nothing to be alarmed about.
Ah. When you say “nothing to be alarmed about” do you in fact mean “Something to be really quite alarmed about”?
Not at all. It’s not a formal meeting. Not as such.
Right. (BEAT) Actually, if it’s all the same to you, could I record it anyway?
Now, why on earth would you want to do that?
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 7 of 129
Well. You know. So I can have a record of it. See if I can’t work out where I’m going wrong.
As I said, this isn’t a formal meeting.
Forgive me, ma’am, but it does sound a little like a formal meeting to me.
Fine. Be my guest. Record whatever you like.
Thanks. I’1ll use my regular Dictaphone.
I have to say: that Dictaphone has won you few friends.
Really? Why’s that?
If you need to ask...
WILL TAKES A DICTAPHONE FROM HIS POCKET, LAYS IT ON THE TABLE BEFORE THEM AND PRESSES RECORD. HE SPEAKS INTO IT.

(TO DICTAPHONE) Recording. Recording. One two three. These are the audio minutes of a meeting held in the Huntsman pub in Clapham Junction at eighteen hundred hours on the twenty- seventh of September. Present are Science Officer Elizabeth Klein (Ph.D) and Junior Science Officer William Arrowsmith. (BEAT) There.
Right. OK. It has been put to me in the past that I can be too formal in my manner. The word “frosty” has been used. As has “aloof”. As has “unapproachable”.
I find that hard to believe.
So I thought we’d have this conversation out of the office. In more relaxed surroundings.
Good idea. You can’t beat a bit of team bonding.
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 8 of 129
This is not intended as a review of your performance, let alone a disciplinary. Though officially, you are still on probation, of course.
Oh, I’m quite aware of that. The sooner I get to become a fully-fledged member of staff, the better.
And that’s what I wanted to talk to you about.
You’re not happy with my work?

Your theoretical work is excellent. Your papers are superbly researched. Your knowledge is extensive. At times, you’re a positive databank. Yet your practical contributions... Your work in the field...
I am trying, Dr Klein.
I know. But I don’t suppose I really have to mention the debacle in Bangalore? The beached Temperon at Yarmouth Pier? The heat vampire who, thanks to your inaction, is still at large in Mexico City?
I am learning. From all my mistakes.

I know. I know you’re doing your best. It just occurred to me that I ought to have a friendly word with you. Our organisation is very large. You don’t have to work in the field. There are research posts. Desk jobs which might be more suited to your particular skills. (BEAT) I’m sorry, Mr Arrowsmith. (BEAT) I am trying to help. (BEAT) I know this must be disappointing but, really, I think you could at least show some sign that you’re listening to me.
Sorry. I didn’t mean to be rude. Don’t turn around, but I think he’s here. Watching us from over by the bar.
Who’s here? Who’s watching us?
You know who, Dr Klein. Him.
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 9 of 129
(BEAT) Which version?
The little one. With the straw hat.
The umbrella man.
According to everything we have on file, he’s generally considered the most dangerous of them. Would you agree with that?
No comment. But what’s he doing here?
Could be a coincidence.
Where he’s concerned, there’s no such thing.
FX: BARSTOOL PUSHED ASIDE, OFF.
Right. He’s standing up.
FX: OFF, DOCTOR BEGINS TO WALK TO DOOR THROUGH:
Is he coming over?
No. No. He’s turning away. (FX: OFF, DOCTOR PULLS OPEN DOOR AND EXITS. DOOR SWINGS SHUT) He’s leaving.
I’m going to follow him. His being back means serious trouble.
I want to go with you. I want to meet him.
No. You report in. Tell them we’ve got a new blue box incident underway. Can you do that?
Of course, but I’d rather come [with you]
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 10 of 129
I think we’ve established you’re not a field man, Will. So I’m giving you a direct order. Understood?
Understood.
I’m going after him. (BEAT) You can turn that thing off now. And wipe the tape.
FX: KLEIN GETS UP AND STRIDES TOWARDS THE DOOR.
Goodbye, Dr Klein!
WILL WAITS UNTIL SHE LEAVES. THEN HE PICKS UP THE DICTAPHONE AND SPEAKS HURRIEDLY INTO IT.

(TO DICTAPHONE) Klein has left the building. (BEAT) And I’ve taken an executive decision to disobey my orders and follow her. Show her what I can really do in the field. (STARSTRUCK) Besides — that was him. The Umbrella Man. The Doctor!
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 11 of 129
SCENE 3. EXT. STREET
FX: RAIN. FOOTSTEPS. THE DOCTOR HURRIES DOWN THE STREET. KLEIN
FOLLOWS.
Doctor! Doctor, wait!
THE DOCTOR HURRIES ON.
Doctor! Slow down!
THE DOCTOR SHOWS NO SIGN THAT HE HAS HEARD HER.
Curse the man.
SHE HURRIES AFTER HIM.
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 12 of 129
SCENE 4. EXT. PUB
FX: RAIN.
WILL EMERGES FROM THE PUB, SPEAKING EXCITEDLY INTO HIS DICTAPHONE.
(TO DICTAPHONE) This is Will Arrowsmith in pursuit of Elizabeth Klein who is herself in pursuit of a person whom I think we’re
able to identify, pretty conclusively, as our former scientific advisor. I’m going after them.
FX: TAPE CLICKS OFF.
SCENE 5. EXT. FURTHER ALONG STREET
A MOMENT’S SILENCE, THEN RECORDING RECOMMENCES.

(TO DICTAPHONE) Arrowsmith here. We’ve been walking for about ten minutes, but at least it’s stopped raining. We’ve left the high street and we’re heading up Lavender Hill. For a moment I thought we were going towards the station but no, we just kept on walking. So far I’ve not been spotted.
THE MACHINE IS SWITCHED OFF. A MOMENT’S SILENCE, THEN...
SCENE 6. EXT. BY BATTERSEA ARTS CENTRE
THE MACHINE IS SWITCHED ON AGAIN.

(TO DICTAPHONE) Right. We’re by the Battersea Arts Centre (of all places) where we seem to have come to a halt. And I’ve just seen why. The TARDIS is here. I’d have thought it’s pretty unignorable but people seem to be passing by without giving it a second glance. It’s wonderful to finally see it for myself. The Doctor’s gone inside and Klein has followed. The door’s been left ajar. I hardly dare approach it.
FX: WILL WALKS UP TO THE TARDIS AND REACHES OUT TO TOUCH THE
EXTERIOR.
Oh. Oh, the stories are true. It really does feel... alive.
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 13 of 129
SCENE 7. INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
FX: KLEIN WALKING AROUND CONSOLE, CALLING OUT.
Doctor? Doctor? I know you’re here, in your Ship. (BEAT) Where are you hiding?
FX: SHE LEAVES THE CONTROL ROOM AND WALKS FURTHER INTO THE
TARDIS.
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 14 of 129
SCENE 8. EXT. BY BATTERSEA ARTS CENTRE
(TO DICTAPHONE) I know this is in direct contravention of my orders but I hope it will show some real initiative on my part. I’m going in.
FX: HE OPENS THE DOOR AND WALKS INSIDE, INTO...
SCENE 9. INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM

(TO DICTAPHONE) Ah. Right. This is a later version of the flight deck so it’s all very Victorian. Well, pseudo-Victorian. Inspired by The Time Machine but rather more by the film version, I’d have said, than by the actual book. No sign of Dr Klein. Nor of our erstwhile Scientific Advisor. I suppose I should go back now. I ought to make my report. But I can’t help myself. I think I’m going to go further in.
FX: THE DOORS SLAM SHUT
(TO DICTAPHONE) And since the doors have just slammed shut it’s
not like I have much choice.
TENTATIVELY, HE WALKS THROUGH THE CONSOLE ROOM AND INTO THE TARDIS.
FX: THE TIME ROTOR STARTS TO RISE AND FALL. THE TARDIS STARTS
TO DEMATERIALISE.
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 15 of 129
SCENE 10. INT. TARDIS — STAR CHAMBER
KLEIN ENTERS A HUGE ROOM WITH A GLASS WALL WHICH LOOKS OUT, IN THE MANNER OF AN AQUARIUM, ONTO A GREAT SEA OF STARS.
THE DOCTOR IS STANDING BEFORE THE GLASS, WATCHING.
(WALKING UP) At last. There you are.
Hello, Elizabeth.
What is this place?
I call it the Star Chamber.
That’s uncharacteristically literal of you. (BEAT) What am I looking at here?

A minor galaxy from the Tier of Ragged Restoration, out towards the universal core. It was under threat from an insatiable intelligent virus. So I materialised my Ship around the stars and prevented their destruction.
You keep an entire galaxy in one room in your TARDIS?
At the moment, yes, I do.
Is it safe?
From here, behind the glass. Perfectly. (BEAT) Probably.
I’ve some questions to ask you.
You sound stressed, Elizabeth. You really ought to spend more time like this. Like me. Just gazing at the stars. It gives one a tremendous sense of perspective.
What were you doing in London? Why were you spying on me?
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 16 of 129
Spying? I just didn’t want to intrude.
But if you’re here.. that means bad news, doesn’t it?
You know, I’m really not used to this reaction when I drop in unannounced on old friends. They’re usually overjoyed to see me. (BEAT) Well, most of them. (BEAT) Some of them.
You're being evasive.
Evasive? Does that really sound like me?
Yes.
The truth is I only dropped by to see that you were well and thriving. You have my old job, after all. I never expected you to come after me. Never dreamed you'd follow me into the TARDIS.
You were only dropping by? You’ve not brought any extra- dimensional horrors with you?
Not this time. (BEAT) But seeing as you’re here, why not join me on a trip or two?
You have no companion at present?
Not at present.
Where’s Raine?
She is.. elsewhere. I’m quite alone. So how about it? A quick sprint about the universe?
I have responsibilities, Doctor. I can’t just take off on some intergalactic jaunt.
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 17 of 129
Ah. Then I rather think I owe you an apology.
Why?
Because the TARDIS has been in flight for the past five minutes.
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 18 of 129
SCENE 11. INT. TARDIS — A LONG, EMPTY CORRIDOR
THE DICTAPHONE IS SWITCHED ON AGAIN.

(TO DICTAPHONE) I think the Ship might be moving. It’s very strange. There’s the sensation of flight but not in the same way you’d feel it in a car or a plane. I suppose it has to do with the nature of whatever it is we’re passing through. My heart rate has increased and I’ve started to perspire. I admit I didn’t expect to find this so alarming. I’ve already passed numerous peculiar rooms full of the most bizarre and unexpected things. I’ve seen cupboards the size of cathedrals and what I think must have been a fridge-freezer full of vegetarian food which extended as far as the eye could see. There are libraries stacked with impossible books. A cinema showing films in five dimensions. Though I’ve yet to see the slightest sign of the Doctor or Klein. Somehow, being here, it feels more like stepping into a man’s mind than into a real place. OK. I’m going to try another door.
WILL OPENS THE DOOR AND STEPS GINGERLY INTO...
SCENE 12. INT. TARDIS — JUNGLE ROOM [CONTINUOUS]
. WHAT APPEARS TO BE A DENSE PATCH OF JUNGLE.
FX: JUNGLE SOUNDS!
(TO DICTAPHONE) This is really very odd.
WILL MOVES FURTHER INTO THE ROOM.
(TO DICTAPHONE) I think I’m probably slightly afraid now.
FX: THE SLITHERING HOWL OF AN ALIEN SLOTH.
(TO DICTAPHONE, HOARSE, BLAIR WITCH STYLE WHISPER) And I think there might be something in here with me.
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 19 of 129
SCENE 13. INT. TARDIS — STAR CHAMBER
Have you kidnapped me?!
Of course not. What a ridiculous suggestion. Am I the sort of person who goes around kidnapping people? Is that really my modus operandi?
You lured me aboard your Ship, then you took off without my consent!
The dematerialisation was not of my doing. You know how temperamental the TARDIS can be. Since her refit she’s grown positively mercurial.
You should take me back at once.
‘Should’, Elizabeth? You don’t sound sure. (BEAT) Admit it, you’re curious. You wonder what will be on the other side of the doors when my TARDIS lands.
(WAVERING) I don’t deny I feel a certain, natural level of curiosity.
FX: DISTANTLY — THE TARDIS MATERIALISES.
Ah. And there we are. The TARDIS has materialised. It can only have been a short hop. Won’t you accompany me to the console room, to see where we’ve ended up? (BEAT) Surely you want to know?
Well, I suppose —
You’re like me, aren’t you? You always want to know.
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 20 of 129
SCENE 14. INT. LARGE BARREL ON SEA

WILL IS IN ANOTHER IMPOSSIBLE ROOM IN THE TARDIS. IT LOOKS LIKE A ROOM TO HIM BUT IT IS IN FACT A LARGE WOODEN BARREL ADRIFT ON AN OCEAN CONTAINED WITHIN THE TARDIS. WILL DOESN'T KNOW IT YET, BUT HE’S ONLY A FEW FEET FROM SHIPWRECK.
THE DICTAPHONE IS SWITCHED ON AGAIN.

(TO DICTAPHONE) Right. I’m in a small oval room which seems to be made entirely of wood. It sounds absurd but I think whatever I’m in is actually floating on water somehow. It’s as though we’ve gone to sea. I’ve not got the faintest idea how or where or (exactly what)-
FX: THE WOODEN BARREL CRASHES ONTO SIDE OF JETTY AND BREAKS UP.
WATER POURS IN.
YELPS AND SHRIEKS IN DISBELIEF
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 21 of 129
SCENE 15. INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
FX: THE DOCTOR IS ATTENDING TO THE TARDIS, TAKING READINGS AND
FLIPPING SWITCHES.
So? Where are we?
The outskirts of Diisseldorf, Germany, May 1945.
Dusseldorf?!
Just one month after the city was liberated by American forces. By the view from outside, we’re somewhere underground. It all seems terribly quiet. Shall we take a stroll?
You’re quite sure the TARDIS has brought us here of her own volition?
From time to time she has these little whims.
And you played no part in it?
How could I have done? You know me. I’ve never really been able to control my Ship. She’s always had a mind of her own.
FX: THE TARDIS DOORS OPEN, SEEMINGLY OF THEIR OWN VOLITION.
You see? Even the doors boss me around.
FX: THE DOCTOR WALKS ACROSS THE CONSOLE ROOM TO THE DOORS. HE
PAUSES. TURNS BACK.
Coming?
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 22 of 129
SCENE 16. INT. TARDIS — ANOTHER LONG CORRIDOR
SODDEN WILL WALKING. SQUELCHING, DRIPPING FOOTSTEPS. THE DICTAPHONE IS SWITCHED ON AGAIN.

(TO DICTAPHONE) I can’t say this has been the easiest day. But I shan’t forget it in a hurry. I suppose I was lucky to crash into that jetty. I’ve found my way back to the central corridor now and it looks very much as though we’ve landed. The Doctor and Klein must be somewhere nearby.
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 23 of 129
SCENE 17. INT. LARGE, HANGAR-LIKE AREA IN UNDERGROUND BASE
(WALKING TO STOP) Where are we, Doctor?
You tell me.
You expect me to recognise this place?
I expect you to observe. I expect you to deduce.
Well, you were right. We are underground. Some sort of scientific establishment, I think.
Very good.

German, of course. It seems badly damaged. Deserted so I’d say it was evacuated. And it must have been ransacked. Judging from all this ash that’s underfoot they tried to torch the place. Looters, do you think?
Looters? Or liberators? Heroes or opportunists? Who can say? It’s history who chooses. And she’s a most unreliable judge.
What are you talking about?
The question is: was the looting random or did it have a purpose? This is Europe after the war, remember. The victors are doing everything they can to acquire the secrets of those who lost.
Scientific secrets, you mean?
All of the Allies — British, American, Russian alike — are engaged in a sordid competition to secure the greatest minds in Nazi Germany for themselves.
You think that’s what’s happened here? Some sort of raid for tech and knowledge?
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 24 of 129
Oh, I’ve no idea. Ignore me. I’m just thinking aloud.
It’s a plausible enough hypothesis. If it hadn’t been for Nazi science, America wouldn’t have won the moon race.
And didn’t Wernher have trouble with the prototype?
I suppose you were there.
I will be.
Doctor?
DOCTOR? Hmm?
What’s that? Someone’s daubed something on the wall.
FX: KLEIN WALKS OVER TO THE FAR SIDE OF THE HANGAR TO EXAMINE
THE FAR WALL MORE CLOSELY. THE DOCTOR FOLLOWS.
It says “Struwwelpeter”. That’s a German word. Shouldn’t the TARDIS have translated it?
As I said. She’s in a whimsical temper. But you evidently recognise the phrase.

Yes. It means “Shockheaded Peter”. From a book by Heinrich Hoffman. A cautionary tale for children about a boy who wouldn’t cut his hair or trim his nails. He becomes a kind of monster. My mother read it to me when I was small.
Did she now? We tell our children such strange stories.
My parents were German, you know. They brought their stories with them. They came over after the war. It can’t have been easy for them.
No, it wasn’t. But they were brave people. Mutte and Ralf.
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 25 of 129
(SHARPLY) How do you know my parents’ names?
Oh, I’m the umbrella man... remember?
So you have been checking up on me. Creepy, Doctor. Decidedly creepy.
You were telling me about “Struwwelpeter”.
I haven’t thought about it in years. What’s it doing here?
I’ve not the slightest notion.
Oh, so this is another coincidence? Like the TARDIS bringing me to this country, in this time?
Coincidences in the universe are like confetti at a wedding. Now shall we go on? I usually find that exploration leads to answers. Of one kind or another.
Yes, I should very much like some answers.
After you, then, Elizabeth.
(RESIGNED) Fine, Doctor. Fine.
FX: THE DOCTOR AND KLEIN WALK ON.
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 26 of 129
SCENE 18. INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
THE DICTAPHONE IS TURNED BACK ON AGAIN.
(TO DICTAPHONE) Right. Back in the control room. Hallelujah. Only it’s empty. The logical conclusion is that the Doctor and Klein have gone outside the TARDIS, wherever that [may be]
FX: DOORS OPEN THEMSELVES, JUST OFF.
Ah. This might be them now.
FX: WALKS FORWARD TO DOORS, POKES HEAD OUT. CROSS TO:
SCENE 19. INT. LARGE, HANGAR-LIKE AREA IN UNDERGROUND BASE
Doctor? Dr Klein? Hello?
BEAT
(INTO DICTAPHONE) No, no sign. In that case, I’m left with two choices. The first is to remain in the TARDIS, in relative safety. The other is to go out. Into the field. (BEAT) Wish me luck.
HE TURNS THE DICTAPHONE OFF.
FX: WILL WALKS AWAY.
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 27 of 129
SCENE 20. INT. RANSACKED LIBRARY IN UNDERGROUND BASE
FX: DOCTOR POKING UMBRELLA IN PILES OF BOOKS ON FLOOR
I wonder, was this a library?
There’s that word again. Daubed on the wall. “Struwwelpeter”.
“Just look at him! there he stands, With his nasty hair and hands.
See! his nails are never cut;
They are grimed as black as soot; And the sloven, I declare,
Never once has combed his hair; Anything to me is sweeter
Than to see... Struwwelpeter.”
That’s it! That’s just how the poem goes. (BEAT) But why on earth have you memorised it?
I didn’t know I had. No idea where it came from. It just popped into my head.
I don’t like seeing that word up there somehow. Not in this place. It seems, I don’t know. It seems... ominous.
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 28 of 129
SCENE 21. INT. GLOOMY DEAD-END CORRIDOR IN UNDERGROUND BASE
AT THE END OF A LONG CORRIDOR, IN A SECRET COMPARTMENT, HINTERBERGER IS WAITING.
FROM HINTERBERGER’S POINT OF VIEW, WE HEAR WILL APPROACH.
HOARSE AND PANICKED BREATHING
(BEYOND PANEL, CALLING OUT, APPROACHING) Doctor? Dr Klein? I’m very sorry, but it’s Will Arrowsmith here!
FX: A HIDDEN PANEL IN THE WALL SLIDES BACK AND HINTERBERGER
EMERGES, SHAKING WITH RAGE.
Get out! Go away! Leave!
(SURPRISED) Aagh! (BEAT) You really scared me, jumping out of the wall like that. —
Why have you come back here? Why do you people persist on coming back? He’s not here anymore. You understand me? He has gone.
Sorry. I don’t mean to intrude. I’m looking for a couple of friends. Well, I say friends. One’s more of a colleague. The other I’ve never met before today. Though I’ve read a lot about him.
Who are you? Where are you from?
My name’s William Arrowsmith. People generally call me Will.
You are English?

Yes. And from the look of this place you’re presumably German. Now, no doubt you’re wondering exactly how it is that we can understand one another. I have a little of your language but not nearly enough to approach this level of fluency. No, what it is is the telepathic circuits of the TARDIS which enable us both to (understand one another)-
PERSUASION by Jonathan Barnes (FINAL) Page 29 of 129
Enough of this gibbering!
Sorry, was I gibbering? It’s just me in the field, being rubbish. Or so I’m told.

SHEPHERDESS: And by some secret art been wholly changed.
